Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Sustaining Ecosystem Services to Support Rapidly Urbanizing Areas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the development of an interdisciplinary graduate program in Ecosystem Services for Urbanizing Regions at Portland State University, in collaboration with Heritage University, and an array of city, state, and federal agencies, and community partners. Ecosystem services are the conditions and processes provided by natural ecosystems that sustain and fulfill human life. Rapid urbanization has contributed to widespread degradation of ecosystem services, thus creating a demand for scientists and managers who can address these issues. This program integrates scholarship from economics, environmental science, engineering, geosciences, urban studies and planning, business administration and social sciences to understand the complex roles that ecosystem services play in supporting rapidly growing urban areas of the Pacific Northwest and beyond.

Trainees will engage in a three-year study sequence, in research, and in field placements to develop an in-depth, interdisciplinary knowledge of ecosystem service issues at multiple scales. A diverse faculty team will build a curriculum and research program that integrates ecological, social, and economic concepts and that explicates the role of values in planning and management. Through new problem-based curricula, research, and community partnerships, the program will create a new generation of scientists and managers proficient in the science and cutting-edge management approaches for sustaining vital ecosystem services for urbanizing regions. Trainees' dissertations will be required to include a co-authored chapter on an interdisciplinary topic, deepening student understanding of the relationships between the natural and social sciences, and providing training for collaborative projects. Trainees also will have an opportunity to complete PSU's Graduate Certificate in Sustainability while pursuing a doctorate. National recruitment for the program will target high-caliber students, with an emphasis on under-represented groups, through a partnership with Heritage University.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Portland State University IGERT program took NSF’s goal of training doctoral students to engage real-world problems through interdisciplinary perspectives seriously. Our IGERT, the Ecosystem Services supporting Urbanizing Regions (ESUR-IGERT), began as a set of graduate classes taught by a multidisciplinary group of seven faculty members, from six departments across three schools and colleges at Portland State University. This unusual combination of faculty brought their different lenses to the problems of ecosystem services (ES) and its relevance in supporting urbanizing regions. One of the many positive results of this wide collaboration is that students were influenced, and challenged, by a broad range of perspectives.

In their IGERT-specific courses, in their IGERT-specific committees, and in their discipline-specific research, the students confronted multiple theoretical lenses and worldviews. The result is a group of students who see problems from an interdisciplinary view and demand that solutions deal with the reality of an interdisciplinary world. The program included a set of requirements designed to demand and encourage interdisciplinary perspectives, including unique courses and co-curricular activities. These requirements resulted in a diverse portfolio of research accomplishments and on-going work.

The most important outcomes of the ESUR-IGERT, however, are not the individual results of one or multiple scientific studies. Rather, the most important outcomes resulted from developing research streams that engaged multiple students and faculty mentors from different scientific disciplines, using a variety of scientific methodologies, to address complex (wicked) problems of social and environmental importance.

Students accepted into our IGERT came from disciplines as disparate as engineering, environmental studies, public administration, and anthropology. Students all participated in a yearlong course sequence centered on ecosystem services. Each course in the sequence had both social science and natural science instructors in the room simultaneously. This combination of faculty and students from a variety of disciplines, with various worldviews, resulted in pushing all the participants to challenge their prior conceptions and to consider the broader implications of seemingly straight-forward problems.

As just one example of the impact of broad disciplinarity, students began addressing problems of social justice by recognizing the inter-related issues of systematically disenfranchised human populations and environmental degradation. Instead of addressing these issues as discrete, our students worked across disciplines using multiple methodologies to address the overall problems more systemically. As a result of this research stream, our students engaged with and studied the impacts of 1) projected cleanup of polluted river sites in the presence of homeless populations deriving subsistence livings from the sites, 2) the farm-to-table agriculture movement and the employment conditions of back-of-the-house restaurant staff and farm workers, 3) subsistence farming and small markets in mountainous central Mexico, and 4) power differentials’ influence on environmental decisions around depleted fisheries in South Pacific nations. All of these studies resulted from broadened perspectives due to the interdisciplinary nature of our IGERT.

The ultimate beneficial outcome of the ESUR-IGERT program is a cadre of scientists who will always look at problems as multi-dimensional and seek solutions that employ knowledge from all sources. This is a cadre of scientists ready to address the wicked problems of our time.
